pull.title: test: apply microsecond precision to test framework logging
pull.body:
When analyzing functional test logs (produced with `combine_logs.py`), entries sometimes sort slightly out of order because even though python prints 6 digits for microsecond precision, it fills up the last 3 digits with zeroes. For example, it may look like a message was received by the test framework before it was sent by the node.

Change this to actually use microsecond precision - this should make combined logs a little bit easier to analyze.

events.message:
test: apply microsecond precision to test framework logging

This makes it easier to compare test and bitcoind logs -
combine_logs.py orders by timestamp and will be more precise.

Tested ACK https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/32676/commits/ed179e0a6528c39b3bca76365f256716f917e19b

Added an `assert(0)` to `feature_abortnode.py` and on this branch, microsecond times are printed, on master (5471e29d057049d2b5a) they are not.

Didn't try to reproduce the described situation in the PR of out-of-order logs, but it makes sense that the existing behavior would result in nonsensical ordering of logs any time you have sub-ms events, and I can recall having run into this before.


<details>

<summary>

### Test logs

</summary> 

```diff
diff --git a/test/functional/feature_abortnode.py b/test/functional/feature_abortnode.py
index a5c8aa163a..8abe487b9e 100755
--- a/test/functional/feature_abortnode.py
+++ b/test/functional/feature_abortnode.py
@@ -37,6 +37,7 @@ class AbortNodeTest(BitcoinTestFramework):
             # Check that node0 aborted
             self.log.info("Waiting for crash")
             self.nodes[0].wait_until_stopped(timeout=5, expect_error=True, expected_stderr="Error: A fatal internal error occurred, see debug.log for details: Failed to disconnect block.")
+        assert(0)
         self.log.info("Node crashed - now verifying restart fails")
         self.nodes[0].assert_start_raises_init_error()
```

The new output is of the same length but of higher precision (replacing the unused 0) 👍 
(keeping it the same format should prevent any parse problems of 3rd party scripts)

- code review  ✅
- compiled & tested ✅

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -837,9 +838,16 @@ def _start_logging(self):
         # User can provide log level as a number or string (eg DEBUG). loglevel was caught as a string, so try to convert it to an int
         ll = int(self.options.loglevel) if self.options.loglevel.isdigit() else self.options.loglevel.upper()
         ch.setLevel(ll)
+
         # Format logs the same as bitcoind's debug.log with microprecision (so log files can be concatenated and sorted)
-        formatter = logging.Formatter(fmt='%(asctime)s.%(msecs)03d000Z %(name)s (%(levelname)s): %(message)s', datefmt='%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S')
-        formatter.converter = time.gmtime
+        class MicrosecondFormatter(logging.Formatter):
+            def formatTime(self, record, _=None):
+                dt = datetime.fromtimestamp(record.created, timezone.utc)
+                return dt.strftime('%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S.%f')
+
+        formatter = MicrosecondFormatter(
+            fmt='%(asctime)sZ %(name)s (%(levelname)s): %(message)s',
+        )
comments.body:
non-blocking question/nit, why is this approach with a derived class of `logging.Formatter` preferable to modifying the `datefmt` string?

```diff
-  formatter = logging.Formatter(fmt='%(asctime)s.%(msecs)03d000Z %(name)s (%(levelname)s): %(message)s', datefmt='%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S')
+  formatter = logging.Formatter(fmt='%(asctime)sZ %(name)s (%(levelname)s): %(message)s', datefmt='%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S.%f')

comments.body:
I tried that too - it doesn't work, it will print 
`2025-06-03T19:12:56.%fZ TestFramework (INFO):`
See https://stackoverflow.com/questions/75035056/microsecond-do-not-work-in-python-logger-format for some background.

comments.body:
> non-blocking question/nit, why is this approach with a derived class of `logging.Formatter` preferable to modifying the `datefmt` string?
> 
> ```diff
> -  formatter = logging.Formatter(fmt='%(asctime)s.%(msecs)03d000Z %(name)s (%(levelname)s): %(message)s', datefmt='%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S')
> +  formatter = logging.Formatter(fmt='%(asctime)sZ %(name)s (%(levelname)s): %(message)s', datefmt='%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S.%f')
> ```

Does it work locally? The docs say:

> The %f format directive only applies to [strptime()](https://docs.python.org/3/library/time.html#time.strptime), not to [strftime()](https://docs.python.org/3/library/time.html#time.strftime). However, see also [datetime.datetime.strptime()](https://docs.python.org/3/library/datetime.html#datetime.datetime.strptime) and [datetime.datetime.strftime()](https://docs.python.org/3/library/datetime.html#datetime.datetime.strftime) where the %f format directive [applies to microseconds](https://docs.python.org/3/library/datetime.html#format-codes).

https://docs.python.org/3/library/time.html#time.strftime

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -837,9 +838,16 @@ def _start_logging(self):
         # User can provide log level as a number or string (eg DEBUG). loglevel was caught as a string, so try to convert it to an int
         ll = int(self.options.loglevel) if self.options.loglevel.isdigit() else self.options.loglevel.upper()
         ch.setLevel(ll)
+
         # Format logs the same as bitcoind's debug.log with microprecision (so log files can be concatenated and sorted)
-        formatter = logging.Formatter(fmt='%(asctime)s.%(msecs)03d000Z %(name)s (%(levelname)s): %(message)s', datefmt='%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S')
-        formatter.converter = time.gmtime
+        class MicrosecondFormatter(logging.Formatter):
+            def formatTime(self, record, _=None):
comments.body: by the way, I switched to `_=None` because `datefmt=None` runs into a linter error (`unused variable 'datefmt'` ), and omitting the arg is not allowed (TypeErrors). Not sure if the linter is correct to complain about this.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -837,9 +838,16 @@ def _start_logging(self):
         # User can provide log level as a number or string (eg DEBUG). loglevel was caught as a string, so try to convert it to an int
         ll = int(self.options.loglevel) if self.options.loglevel.isdigit() else self.options.loglevel.upper()
         ch.setLevel(ll)

         # Format logs the same as bitcoind's debug.log with microprecision (so log files can be concatenated and sorted)
-        formatter = logging.Formatter(fmt='%(asctime)s.%(msecs)03d000Z %(name)s (%(levelname)s): %(message)s', datefmt='%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S')
-        formatter.converter = time.gmtime
+        class MicrosecondFormatter(logging.Formatter):
+            def formatTime(self, record, _=None):
comments.body: I can see it fail if python internally passes `datefmt` as a keyword arg. I can see disabling the linter, because it may be wrong due to this. I can also see just saying `assert not datefmt` to ensure it is `None` and ensure the keyword is used. But no strong opinion. I think anything is fine here.

comments.body: I don't have a strong opinion either, I just wanted to mention this because `_=None` may look weird to some - if the current approach is fine I'll just leave it at this.

comments.body: Ah, thanks for the context, I hadn't checked since I assumed the  format specifiers would not differ between `datetime.datetime.strftime()` and `strftime()`, but I can confirm that applying the diff I suggest, the logs look exactly as @mzumsande indicated, and the microseconds are not printed.
